ideology_summary: Cynical realist who sees most people as conformist and corporate culture as entitled, but holds hope for individuals who step out of the herd.
summary_chunks: The Line and the Leash depicts a corporate line where clerks ask dumb questions to assert control.
The herd follows because it’s easier to conform than to choose.
The narrator condemns corporate entitlement and the fear it exploits.
Individuals who step out of the line are rare but real, and they break the shape.
The chapter ends urging the traveler to choose the path instead of the ritual.
lesson: The line is a ritual; the path is a choice.
Corporate power feeds on fear and entitlement.
Most people follow the herd; individuals can step out.
The clerk’s power is only as big as the fear you give it.
One person stepping out breaks the shape.
subtitle: In which the traveler learns the herd follows the line, but the person can step out.
